# importing the required libraries
import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

# Libraries for data visualisation
import plotly.express as px
import plotly.graph_objects as go
import plotly.io as pio
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
import seaborn as sns


import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))
source.40562291:
# Changing the date to relevant datatype
medium_df['date']=pd.to_datetime(medium_df['date'])
medium_df.head()
source.b8581119:
claps = medium_df.groupby('publication')['claps'].sum().sort_values(ascending = False).reset_index()
plt.figure(figsize = (10,8))
px.bar(claps, x= 'publication', y='claps', color = 'publication',
       title="Claps for various Publishers" )
source.215ea465:
reps = medium_df.groupby('publication')['responses'].sum().sort_values(ascending = False).reset_index()
plt.figure(figsize = (10,8))
px.bar(reps, x= 'publication', y='responses', color = 'publication',
       title="Responses for various Publishers" )
source.7af7e584:
## Visualisation for Reading Time
read = medium_df.groupby('publication')['reading_time'].sum().sort_values(ascending = False).reset_index()
plt.figure(figsize = (10,8))
px.bar(read, x= 'publication', y='reading_time', color = 'publication',
       title="Reading Time for various Publishers" )
source.a1537959:
medium_df['month'] = medium_df['date'].dt.month
medium_df_gr = medium_df.groupby('month')['publication'].count().sort_values(ascending = False).reset_index()
plt.figure(figsize = (10,8))
px.bar(medium_df_gr, x= 'month', y='publication', color = 'publication',hover_data=['publication'],
       title="Month wise Publication" )
source.dc7fcd49:
sns.countplot(medium_df['publication'])
plt.xticks(rotation = 90)
plt.title('Publications With Number Of Articles')
source.f0456fdc:
dis = ['claps','responses','reading_time']
dist = pd.DataFrame(medium_df[dis])
fig = plt.figure(figsize = (16,12))
for index,col in enumerate(dist):
    plt.subplot(3,2,index+1)
    sns.boxplot(x = dist.loc[:,col])
fig.tight_layout(pad=1.0)
source.938ff822:
all_publication = medium_df.groupby('publication')['reading_time'].sum().sort_values(ascending = False)
fig = px.pie(all_publication,values = all_publication.values, names=all_publication.index,
            title='Publication with Highest Reading Time')
fig.show()
source.4efba23d:
pub_clap = medium_df.groupby('title')['claps'].max().sort_values(ascending= False).head(10).reset_index()
px.bar(pub_clap, x= 'title', y='claps', 
       title="Articles with Highest Claps" )
source.7771d282:
pub_resp = medium_df.groupby('title')['responses'].max().sort_values(ascending= False).head(10).reset_index()
px.bar(pub_resp, x= 'title', y='responses',title="Articles with Highest responses" )
source.1e793f63: Lets look at some of the visualisation of data
source.54822475: Most of the publications were done in the month of may and the lowest publication was in month of December
source.771ccc07:
- The number of claps for many articles is around 0.
- Also the number of responces is quite low. This shows that most articles have less number of comments
- The average time taken to read an article is around 5-9 minutes. This tells that the articles are short or readers glance through the articles and jump to concusions.
source.678690e1: Some of the articles in Medium have no subtitles
source.3c47efa9:
The columns have different data types
- 'url','title','subtitle', 'publication' have [object] datatype
- 'id','claps','responces','reading_time' have numerical datatype
- 'date' has data in date format
source.b8a6874d: **'The Startup' has the highest reading time.**
source.b3cf8332: 'The Startup' has the largest number of articles
source.5087411a: Article with the Highest Claps with the value
